title: Tracking and characterization of partial and full epithelial-mesenchymal transition cells in a mouse model of metastatic breast cancer
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part 1
Tissue harvesting
Timing: 30 min
This section details the collection of mammary tumors for individual downstream analysis.
Sterilize surfaces, forceps, scalpels, and surgical scissors with 70% ethanol.
Euthanize the mouse using CO2
Dissect mammary tumors:
Place mouse on its back, stretch-out and pin-down on all four limbs.
Spray the abdomen with 70% ethanol and wipe-off excess liquid.
Use forceps and a surgical scissor to make an incision extending from the bottom of the abdomen to the thorax. Extend the incision along the limbs to create an x-shape.
Note: Avoid piercing the peritoneum as the mammary tumors are located between the skin and the peritoneum.
Separate the skin from the peritoneum to expose the tumors. Using two forceps, gently pull the skin to the sides and use a scalpel to separate it from the abdomen if necessary. Pin down the stretched-out skin.
Using a scalpel, dissect all individual mammary tumors and the surrounding mammary fat pad.
Critical: Early-stage nodules may be peeled off the skin by gentle pulling. If tumors have grown into the skin, do not forcefully detach them, but collect a wider range of tissue to contain disseminated cancer cells.
Note: A tail or ear biopsy may be collected from the animal to verify the genotyping results.
Continue with downstream processing:
Prepare paraffin and/or OCT frozen tissue blocks with 1–2 pieces (3–5 mm in diameter) of tumors from individual mammary tumors as described in the study by Lüönd and Sugiyama et al. (Luond et al., 2021[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9]). These blocks can be stored at room temperature (around 25°C) and at −80°C, respectively, and used for staining later.
For the tumor slice culture and/or single-cell isolation, follow the protocols described below in part 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.2] and part 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.3], respectively.

Note: MMTV-PyMT mice develop multiple tumors in all mammary fat pads. Early and late-stage lesions will be present at harvest. To account for tumor heterogeneity, collect tumors from multiple locations (e.g., center and periphery as well as solid and soft areas) for sliced tissue culture and for 5 cell RNAseq.
Part 2
Tumor slicing
Timing: 1 h
This section describes the preparation of mammary tumor slices for live-cell imaging using a vibrating blade microtome instrument such as the Leica VT 1200S vibratome (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1710-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Preparation of agarose blocks for tissue slicing using a vibratome
(A) Schematic illustration of the preparation of fresh tissue-embedded agarose blocks for tumor slicing. Mammary tumors are collected from transgenic EMT lineage tracing mouse models. 3–5 tumor pieces (around 5 × 5 × 5 mm in size) are collected from individual tumors and kept on ice. Using a 10 mL syringe, 3% agarose solution is poured into a Peel-A-Way histology mold to make a thin layer of agarose (agarose bed). Once agarose has solidified, a piece of tumor is placed on the agarose bed and agarose solution is added over the top of tumor piece in the mold until the tissue is entirely covered (fully embedded).
(B) Schematic illustration of the relative positions of the sample on specimen disc and a blade as well as approaching direction of the blade for tissue slicing using a vibratome. Of note, the location of the tumor piece embedded in the agarose gels should be in close proximity to the blade to increase the stability during slicing.
Using a scalpel, collect 3 to 5 small pieces of tumors (3–5 mm diameter) from individual mammary tumors. Gently remove excess adipose tissue from the tumor pieces and keep them in DMEM/F12 medium placed on ice.

Embed tumors in 3% low-melting agarose (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A):
Using a 10 mL syringe, put warm (≈ 37°C) 3% low-melting agarose solution (in sterile PBS, ≈ 1–2 mL) in a Peel-A-Way histology mold to make a thin layer of agarose.
Place the mold on ice. Agarose will solidify in 5 min.
Once agarose has solidified, place one piece of tumor on top of agarose. The mold should be kept on ice.
Add agarose solution (≈ 5–6 mL) over the top of tumor piece in the mold until the tissue is entirely covered.
Cover with aluminum foil and keep on ice until slicing.
Set up the Leica VT 1200S vibrating blade microtome:
Put a blade into blade holder with an Allen wrench.
Using an Allen wrench, rotate the blade to the clearance angle −18°.
Optimize the position of the blade using the VibroCheck.
After the optimization, secure the blade into the blade holder.
Pop the embedded tissue out of the mold.
Spray the specimen disc and buffer tray of the Leica VT 1200S vibratome with 70% ethanol and wipe-off excess liquid.
Glue the face of the upper side of the agarose block directly to the specimen disc. The embedded tumor that was at the bottom of the mold will now be on top (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B). The glue dries in 3–5 min.
Place the buffer tray into the ice holder of the Leica VT 1200S vibratome. Add ice into the ice holder and fill the buffer tray with ice-cold sterile PBS.
Once the sample embedded in agarose has completely adhered to the specimen disc, place the disc into the buffer tray.
Set the ice tray onto the vibratome stand and lock the tray in place by moving the lever to the right.

Using an Allen wrench, rotate the blade into cutting position with the clearance angle −18°.
Using the control pad, raise the stage up until the blade touches the surface of the agarose gel (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B).
Set the cutting conditions using the control pad:
Set cutting window.
Set section thickness (auto feed, 250–350 μm), amplitude (1–2 mm) and speed (0.1–1.0 mm/s).
Until the blade reaches the tissue, run the vibratome at 1.0 mm/s speed.
Adjust settings on the vibratome depending on the consistency and integrity of the tissue. In most cases, cut the tumors at amplitude 2 mm, speed 0.1 mm/s.
Once uniform slices are obtained, gently scoop them out of the bath using spatulas or forceps. Clean spatulas and forceps with 70% ethanol prior to use.
Transfer them into a 6-well plate containing 2–3 mL of ice-cold DMEM/F12 medium and place the plate on ice. Slices from one piece of tumor can be collected into the same well.
Note: Sliced tumors can be stored for up to 3 h on ice. However, it is recommended to keep them on ice for as short as possible.
Staining of the slices
Timing: 1 h
This section describes the staining of mammary tumor slices with fluorophore-conjugated antibodies for live-cell imaging.
Scoop up one slice from each piece of tumor using a sterile spatula. Place each one slice into one well of a 24-well plate.
Add 300 μL of pre-warmed DMEM/F12 medium for breast tumor slice tissue containing Alexa Fluor-conjugated antibody (for example, Alexa Fluor 647 anti-mouse CD31, 1:50) and incubate for 30 min at 37°C.
Note: Tissues can be incubated with a combination of fluor-conjugated antibodies based on your needs. We have not tested indirect immunofluorescence staining so far.

During the incubation time, prepare a plate for imaging the slice tissue culture. Place one Millicell Cell Culture insert into each well of a 24-well imaging plate using sterile forceps.
Pipette 300 μL of DMEM/F12 medium for breast tumor slice tissue into the well and 50 μL into the insert.
After staining, wash the tissue slices by transferring them twice through separate wells containing 500 μL of pre-warmed DMEM/F12 medium for breast tumor slice tissue using forceps.
Using forceps, gently transfer one slice onto one cell culture insert. Once transferred, use a spatula to gently spread the slice to ensure it lays completely flat on the cell insert membrane.
If necessary, remove excess media from the insert to the outer well to avoid floating and folding of the slice in the insert. Media will eventually equilibrate on its own. The tissue slices are kept at an interface of air and culture media.
Critical: To avoid evaporation during imaging, use the middle rows in the plate for the slice tissue cultures and add sterile water or PBS to one row of wells on each of the four surrounding sides. If more than 8 wells are needed for culture, fill the spaces between wells with sterile water or PBS.
Live-cell imaging
Timing: 2–3 days
This section describes live-cell imaging of mammary tumor slices using a spinning disc confocal microscope (Visitron Systems) to track morphological and behavioral dynamics of partial and full EMT cells within the tumor microenvironment.
Switch on all components of the spinning disc confocal microscope and turn on the computer.
Set up the incubation chamber (Okolab) at 37°C with 5% CO2, 90 ± 5% humidity at least 30 min prior to imaging.
Switch on the individual lasers by turning on the keys.
Start VisiView Premier Image acquisition Software.

Place the imaging plate containing the tissue culture inserts on the microscope stage.
Set up the live-cell imaging using a spinning disc confocal microscope with a CFI Plan Apo 20×, 0.75 NA objective, a Hamamatsu Flash 4.0 V2 CMOS camera, a Yokogawa Spinning Disk.
Open “Acquisition” panel, set up the exposure time for every channel and pixel binning as “2”.
Go to “Wavelength” tab and tick “Wavelength series” box. Select the number of channels and lasers that should be active during acquisition.
Go to “Time-lapse” tab and tick “time-lapse series” box. Set up the time interval and the duration of the acquisition. For tissue slices, we set up 1–2.5 h interval for up to 3 days.
Turn on the Perfect Focus System (PFS) controller.
To maintain the focus, tick “Autofocus always on” box and select “Autofocus on during waiting” option.
Note: PFS automatically maintains microscope focus on the region of interest during live-cell imaging. However, it can interfere with the acquisition of Z-stacks as it will start racing after the piezo stage if it is active during Z-stack acquisition. Therefore, PFS should be active before scanning each setting point and off during Z-stack acquisition.
Go to “Z-series” tab and tick the “Z-plane series” box. Manually define a plane of interest to set “Home position” and then set “Top Offset” and “Bottom Offset” for region of interest.
Go to “Stage” tab and set multiple XYZ points. We recommend to set 2–4 positions per slice to obtain images of different regions of the tumor.
Save the setting for multidimensional live-cell imaging. These can be re-loaded for use at a later time.
Click “sequence” to start live-cell imaging of the slices.

Critical: During long-term imaging of the tissue, pause the image acquisition at every 24 h and carefully replace the medium in the wells with fresh pre-warmed medium using a 200 μL pipette with long tips. Do not touch the slices in the cell culture inserts.
Note: Examples of live cell imaging of early and late EMT mammary tumor cells are shown in Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1] (Representative time lapse movie of mammary tumor slice tissue culture with migrating GFP+ partial EMT tumor cells) and Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1] (Representative time lapse movie of mammary tumor slice tissue culture with migrating GFP+ full EMT tumor cells).

Image processing
Timing: 1–2 days for one slice

This section describes image processing and data analysis of live-cell imaging using ImageJ (ImageJ, U. S. National Institutes of Health) and Arivis Vision4D software (arivis AG). Timings of image processing are for one tumor slice for an experienced researcher.
Open the script (DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.6103102[href=http://10.5281/zenodo.6103102]) to correct three-dimensional positions on ImageJ software.
Press “Run”.
Browse the stk file for drift correction. Set up Z spacing (μm), number of timepoints, number of slices, first position (S) to process, number of positions, name of the different channels, and name of the channel of reference for the registration. We used mCherry as a reference channel for drift correction.
Press “OK” to start the correction. The script corrects the focus drift and, at the same time, makes a movie for each XYZ position. The movies are automatically saved in the folder where the original files are.
Open the movies on Arivis Vision4D software.
Visually inspect the XYZ position and manually adjust it using “drift correction” from “Data” submenu if necessary.
Track the migration of individual GFP-expressing cells that have undergone either partial or full EMT in tumors.
Crop the region of interest using “transformation gallery” from “Data” submenu.
Activate the “Track Cells and Particles” pipeline from Analysis panel.
Select GFP channel for tracking in “Input ROI” panel.
Set up diameter, probability threshold, and split sensitivity in “Blob finder” panel. Check the values by executing the pipeline using step-by-step tool.
Define the minimum volume of the blob filter.
In “Tracking” panel, select “Brownian motion (Centroid)” in “Motion type”. Set max distance 15 μm per hour. Tick “Fusions” and “Divisions” boxes to follow a cell even if this cell is fused with another cell or divides simultaneously.
Check the all settings using step-by-step tool.
Run the pipeline.

Open “Object” panel. Select the features which should be considered during tracking.
Export the results as excel file.
Plot the trajectories of GFP+ cells in tumors on excel. Make a scatter plot with smooth line chart using values of X and Y displacement to start (μm).
Part 3
Preparation of single-cell suspension for flow cytometry
Timing: 4 h
This section describes the enzymatic digestion of the tumor samples to obtain single cell suspensions from murine mammary tumors. Timings of the protocols in part 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec3.3] are adjusted for processing the pooled tissue of all mammary tumors and the adjacent mammary fat pad from one mouse (1–2 mg wet weight). If processing samples from multiple mice, the timing will increase accordingly.
Note: We suggest selecting tumor pieces from multiple individual tumors with different morphology to account for tumor heterogeneity for sliced tissue culture and frozen tissue/paraffin embedding. The remaining tumor tissue and surrounding mammary fat pad is then pooled for digestion and single cell isolation for RNA sequencing. Hence several tumor samples are being used per mouse to generate sufficient single cells for RNA sequencing.
Note: The maximum number of mice to handle at the same time is 2 for an experienced researcher to avoid compromising the quality and viability of the cells.
Critical: For negative controls and single stain control samples required for compensation, collect the mammary tumors from MMTV-PyMT, MMTV-PyMT/RC::FrePe/Tnc-CreERT2 or MMTV-PyMT/RC::FrePe/Cdh2-CreERT2 mice and prepare single-cell suspensions. In these mice, none of the cells express mCherry or GFP. Negative control cells can be frozen in FBS containing 10% DMSO as cryomedium and stored in liquid nitrogen.
Prepare 10 mL collagenase/trypsin solution and DNase solution per mouse and store it on ice.

Note: Once tumor pieces were selected for sliced tissue culture and OCT/paraffin block preparation, pool all remaining mammary tumors from an individual mouse. Do not remove adipose tissue (mammary fat pad) surrounding tumors as it may contain early-stage lesions and disseminated cells.
Place the mammary tumor tissue on the lid of a sterile petri dish and cut it into small pieces (<1 mm) using a scalpel with a sterile blade.
Transfer the chopped-up tissue into a 50 mL Falcon tube containing 10 mL of collagenase/trypsin solution and incubate at 37°C while shaking at 200 rpm for 1 h.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min at room temperature (RT).
Discard the supernatant by carefully decanting the content of the tube.
Add 10 mL of DNase solution and tilt the tube up and down few times for 5 min at RT.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Discard the supernatant by decanting the content of the tube.
Suspend the pellet in 20–40 mL of ice-cold FACS buffer and filtrate into a 50 mL Falcon tube using a 70 μm sterile cell strainer.
Note: After digestion, the cell suspension will still contain small pieces of tumors. Using a plunger of a 5 mL syringe, smash the pieces of tumor on the strainer and wash the strainer with FACS buffer several times.
Determine the total number of cells manually using a hemocytometer.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Discard the supernatant and prepare single-cell suspension at 1 × 106–1 × 107 cells/mL in ice-cold FACS buffer.
Remove immune cells, endothelial cells and red blood cells:
Add blocking antibody (CD16/32, 1:100) and incubate for 5 min on ice.
Add 5 mL of ice-cold FACS buffer.

Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in ice-cold FACS buffer maintaining the cell suspension at 1 × 106–1 × 107 cells/mL.
Add biotin-conjugated CD31, CD45, and Ter-119 antibodies (1:100 dilution for each) and incubate on ice for 20 min.
Add 5 mL of ice-cold FACS buffer.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in ice-cold FACS buffer to reach a cell concentration of 1 × 107 cells/mL. Transfer the cell suspension into a 5 mL polystyrene tube.
Wash 100 μL of Dynabeads biotin binder in 1 mL of FACS buffer, place into an EasySep Magnet and discard the supernatant. The beads are then resuspended in 100 μL of FACS buffer.
Add 100 μL pre-washed Dynabeads per up to 107 total cells. If cell number is bigger than 107 cells, scale up all reagent volumes accordingly.
Mix well and incubate on ice for 30 min.
Place the tube into an EasySep Magnet for 3 min and collect the supernatant by pouring it into a 15 mL falcon tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Remove dead cells using EasySep™ Dead Cell Removal (Annexin V) Kit:
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in ice-cold Dead Cell Removal buffer at 1 × 108 cells/mL. Transfer the suspension into a 5 mL polystyrene tube.
Add 50 μL of Dead Cell Removal (Annexin V) Cocktail and 50 μL of Biotin Selection Cocktail to 1 mL of cell suspension. If the amount of cell suspension is bigger than 1 mL, scale up all reagent volumes accordingly.
Incubate for 3 min at room temperature.
During the incubation, vortex RapidSpheres™ for 30 s.

Add 100 μL of RapidSpheres per 1 mL of sample and immediately add Dead Cell Removal buffer to top up the sample to 2.5 mL.
Place the tube into the EasySep Magnet for 3 min.
Pour the live-cell enriched supernatant into a 15 mL Falcon tube.
Centrifuge the tube at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.
Note: Steps 55 and 56 can be switched.
Stain with Fluorophore-conjugated antibodies.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in FACS buffer to adjust the cell suspension to 1 × 106 cells/100 μL.
Add 1 μL each of APC anti-mouse CD326 (EpCAM) and Brilliant Violet 650™ (BV650) Streptavidin per 100 μL suspension. If the amount of cell suspension is bigger than 100 μL, scale up antibody volumes accordingly.
Incubate for 20 min on ice.
Add 1 mL of FACS buffer and centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 5–15 mL FACS buffer.
Note: Consult with the FACS facility or operator regarding the concentration and volumes of the samples.
Store the samples on ice in the dark until FACS sorting.
At the same time, prepare the experimental control samples.
Prepare experimental control samples in the following tubes:
Non-stained control: unstained sample cells.
Draq7: sample cells stained with Draq7.
APC-FMO: sample cells stained with BV650 Streptavidin and Draq7.
BV650-FMO: sample cells stained with APC EpCAM and Draq7.
Note: Draq7 is added to the samples immediately before loading onto the FACS sorter to stain dead/damaged cells.
Aliquot 50 μL of sample cell suspension for each control samples.
Add 0.5 μL of Brilliant Violet 650™ Streptavidin or APC anti-mouse CD326 (Ep-CAM) in tube iii and tube iv, respectively.
Incubated on ice for 20 min.

Add 1 mL of FACS buffer to tubes i-iv and centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min. Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 200 μL FACS buffer and store on ice in the dark until sorting.
Prepare compensation control samples.
Prepare compensation control samples in the following tubes:
Negative control: unstained negative control cells.
Draq7: negative control cells stained with Draq7.
APC: negative control cells stained with APC EpCAM.
BV650: negative control cells stained with BV650 Streptavidin.
mCherry: single-cell suspension prepared from a mCherry+ cell line.
GFP: single-cell suspension prepared from a GFP+ cell line.
Prepare single-cell suspension of negative control cells at 1 × 106 cells/100 μL and aliquot 50 μL suspension into four microcentrifuge tubes (i-iv). Single-cell suspension of negative control cells prepared from the mammary tumors of MMTV-PyMT, MMTV-PyMT/RC::FrePe/Tnc-CreERT2 or MMTV-PyMT/RC::FrePe/Cdh2-CreERT2 mice should be used. These cells should not contain any mCherry or GFP-expressing cells.
Add 0.5 μL of APC anti-mouse CD326 (Ep-CAM) or Brilliant Violet 650™ Streptavidin in tubes iii and iv, respectively.
Incubate on ice for 20 min.
Add 1 mL of FACS buffer to tubes i-iv and centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min at RT. Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 200 μL FACS buffer and store on ice in the dark until sorting.
For tube v and vi trypsinize mCherry+ and GFP+ cell lines to prepare single-cell suspension.
Note: These cell lines were previously established by isolating mCherry+ and GFP+ breast cancer cells derived from tumors in Tnc-CreERT2/MMTV-Flpo/RC::FrePe/MMTV-PyMT mice. Wash cells once with PBS, add trypsin and incubate at 37°C until cells detach.
After trypsinization, add 10 mL of complete DMEM high glucose medium and centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min at RT.

Remove the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in 200 μL–1 mL of FACS buffer depending on the size of the pellet.
Store tube v and vi on ice in the dark until sorting.
Note: Draq7 is added to the samples immediately before loading onto the FACS sorter to stain dead/damaged cells.
5-Cell sorting of partial and full EMT subpopulations using flow cytometry
Timing: 4–8 h
This section describes the process of 5-cell sorting of subpopulations of partial and full EMT cells using Becton-Dickinson’s FACSAria IIIc. In our partial and full EMT lineage tracing mouse models, mCherry labels breast cancer cells and GFP labels breast cancer cells that have ever undergone either partial or full EMT. Cells expressing both mCherry and GFP are cells just undergoing an EMT (transitioning cells). In this protocol, based on the expression of GFP or mCherry in combination with the epithelial marker EpCAM expression, we focus on the sorting of breast cancer cells in different stages of the EMT spectrum for further RNA sequencing.
Note: All the steps from this section should be performed at 4°C.
Critical: The time from tissue harvesting to 5-cell sorting should be kept as short as possible. Total processing times will depend on the abundance of the target populations, but we recommend to process no longer than 12 h for harvesting healthy cells for RNA sequencing.
Filtrate the experimental sample and all control samples through a 40 μm mesh into 5 mL polystyrene tubes.
Add Draq7 to the experimental sample and Draq7 containing controls. 1 μL of Draq7 is added per 200 μL of cell suspension.
Start the FACSAria IIIc sorter.
Choose a nozzle size of 100 μm.
Set up the side stream and optimize the position of the side streams for 4-way sort using the voltage sliders.

Set up the laser and the following filters:
Draq7 (Laser: Red 633 nm, Mirror: 735LP, Filter: 780/60).
APC (Laser: Red 633 nm, Filter: 660/20).
Brilliant Violet 650 (Laser: Violet 405 nm, Mirror: 635LP, Filter: 670/30).
mCherry (Laser: Yellow/Green 561 nm, Mirror: 600LP, Filter: 610/20).
GFP (Laser: Blue 488 nm, Mirror: 502LP, Filter: 530/30).
Apply negative control (compensation tube step 59a (i)) to set baselines for all channels.
Analyze compensation controls steps 59a (ii)–(vi) to select appropriate laser power and outputs for each of the fluorophores used. Calculate and apply compensation.
Set up the sorting gates using experimental control samples (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]):
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1710-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Gating strategy for the sorting of GFP+ partial and full EMT cells derived from mammary tumors by flow cytometry
Schematic representation of the gating strategy for flow cytometry used to sort GFP+ tumor cells from Tnc-CreERT2 and Cdh2-CreERT2 mice treated with Tamoxifen. Tumor cells are separated from debris by Forward Scatter Area (FSC-A)/Side Scatter Area (SSC-A), and doublets and aggregates are excluded by FSC-A and FSC-height (FSC-H) dot plots. Living Lin- cells are selected by gates on the negative fractions for Draq7 and BV650 Streptavidin (biotinylated-CD31, CD45, and Ter119). Further setting the gates, 4 populations of GFP+ cells (GFP+EpCAM-, GFP+EpCAMlow, GFP+EpCAMmed and GFPhighEpCAMmed), 3 populations of mCherry+ cells (mCherry+EpCAM-, mCherry+EpCAMhigh and mCherryhighEpCAMhigh), and 1 population of double-positive cells (mCherry+ GFP+EpCAM+) are isolated.
Load non-stained experimental control step 58a (i) onto the FACSAria IIIc and verify that the sample cells contain mCherry and GFP-expressing cells.
Set up the gating by selecting the cellular compartment in the Forward Scatter Area (FSC-A) versus Side Scatter Area (SSC-A) dot plot.
Exclude doublets and aggregates using FSC-A and FSC-height (FSC-H).
Set up gating for the negative fraction for Draq7.

Set up a gate for the negative cells for BV650 Streptavidin (biotinylated-CD31, CD45, and Ter119).
Analyze Draq7 control (experimental control step 58a (ii)) to ensure the selection of live cells.
Analyze APC-FMO control (experimental control step 58a (iii)) to ensure that the gates for live Lin- cells are set correctly.
Set up gates for mCherry+, GFP+ and double positive (mCherry+ GFP+) cells.
Set up the gating for the EpCAM- cells in each mCherry+, GFP+ and double positive populations.
Analyze BV650-FMO control (experimental control step 58a (iv)) to ensure the gates for EpCAM- cells.
Set up the gates for 3 populations of mCherry+ cells (mCherry+EpCAM-, mCherry+EpCAMhigh and mCherryhighEpCAMhigh), 4 populations of GFP+ cells (GFP+EpCAM-, GFP+EpCAMlow, GFP+EpCAMmed and GFPhighEpCAMmed) and 1 population of double-positive cells (mCherry+ GFP+EpCAM+) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Open the sort collection chamber door and install 4 tubes of 5 mL polypropylene collection tubes containing 1 mL of FACS buffer on 4-way chamber.
Insert the experimental sample in the sample injection chamber of the sorter.
Start acquisition and verify that the gate settings are correct.
Set up the desired number of events to collect. Proceed with the sorting of 5K cells each for the 3 mCherry+ populations and the 1 mCherry+GFP+ double-positive population.
Critical: Since GFP+ cells are very rare in the mammary tumors, collect as many cells as possible for each of the 4 populations of GFP+ cells from the rest of the sample.

Note: The sorted cells are further applied to 5-cell sorting. We assume that more than 50% of the sorted cells will be lost during this 2nd sorting step. In addition, the number of cells returned from the sorter could differ from the actual number of sorted cells. We recommend to set up the number of events for sorting 5–10 times bigger than of what is aimed at for collection of 5-cell pools, if possible.
Note: In the mammary tumors, we estimate only 0.13% and 0.002% of cancer cells to be partial and full EMT cells, respectively, that are marked as GFP+ cells. Due to the low number of GFP+ cells, around 3–6 h of sorting is needed for each population of GFP+ breast cancer cells.
After collecting the cells in polypropylene collection tubes, centrifuge at 200 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant, but keep approximately 200 μL of liquid. Resuspend the cells in the collection tubes and keep them on ice in the dark.
Note: Consult with the FACS facility or operator regarding the volumes of the samples.
Optimize the position of the side streams for 96-well plates.
Set a MicroAmp® Fast 96-Well Reaction Plate with a transparent lid on the stage in the sorting chamber.
Select Sort > Home Device to access the Device Setup dialog.
Select the desired collection device. In this protocol, “96 well-Falcon”.
Click “Go to Home”. The stage moves to the pre-programmed Home position.
Start test sort. Inspect the plate lid to see where a drop was deposited.
Wipe the lid dry and place it back onto the stage.
Adjust the Home location if the drop did not hit the center of the well.
Repeat e to g until the drop is centered appropriately.
Click arrow buttons to move the tray.

Set up new Home position and check the location of drop deposition as above. We recommend to check one row of wells on each of the four sides of the plate.
Note: Large arrows move the tray by five steps. Small arrows move the tray by one step.
Clean a tissue culture hood with RNaseZap and DNA decontamination reagent before preparing a MicroAmp® Fast 96-Well Reaction Plate for 5-cell sorting. Clean pipettes with RNaseZap. Wipe-off excess liquid.
Pipette 2.3 μL of 0.2% TX-100 in PBS containing 2 U/μL RNase inhibitor into each well of a 96-well plate and store it on ice. Cover plate with RNAse free plate seal.
Note: Choose a type of 96-well plate that is compatible with robot for RNA sequencing library preparation.
Clean the stage in the sorting chamber of FACSAria IIIc with RNaseZap.
Install the plate with well A1 toward the front of the stage.
Note: Sorting starts on the front left corner of the device (A1), and proceeds from front to back, and then from left to right, sorting in a serpentine motion. Thus, for a plate, sorting proceeds from well A1–A12, B12–B1, C1–C12, and so on.
Insert the sample tube in the sample injection chamber of the sorter. In this protocol, 3 tubes for mCherry+, 4 tubes for GFP+ and 1 tube for double-positive populations will be sorted consecutively.
Select target wells for 5-cell sorting.
Start acquisition and sort 5 cells per well of the MicroAmp® Fast 96-Well Reaction Plate.
Repeat for every pre-sorted cell population.
After sorting, seal the plate with an adhesive plate seal and spin down.
Place the plate in a box containing dry ice. Store the plate at −80°C as soon as possible until preparing libraries for RNA sequencing.

Note: One sorting droplet for one cell is ranging from 0.001 μL to 0.005 μL. Therefore, total volume in one well would remain around 2.3 μL after sorting.
5-Cell RNA sequencing
Timing: 2–3 days
This section describes the major steps for the preparation of RNA sequencing libraries according to the Smart-seq2 method (Picelli et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10]) using the low-volume liquid-handling robot Mosquito HV system (SPT Labtech).
Spray the 96-well plate containing 5-cell pools and a cooling rack with RNaseZap and remove the seal. Place the plate on the rack on ice.
Prepare the annealing mixture by combining (per 96-well plate) 90 μL H2O, 10 μL oligo-dT primer (10 μM) and 100 μL dNTP mix (10 mM each). Add 2 μL annealing mix to the 5-cell pool in lysis buffer per well using the Mosquito HV liquid-handling robot.
Cover the plate with an adhesive seal, vortex briefly and spin down.
Incubate the plate at 72°C for 3 min. Centrifuge at 700 × g for 1 min. Transfer the plate back on ice immediately afterward.
Prepare reverse transcription (RT) reaction mix.

Add 5.7 μL of RT mix to the samples. The final reaction volume per well is 10 μL.
Cover the plate with an adhesive seal, vortex briefly and spin down.

Prepare PCR mix for cDNA amplification.

Add 15 μL of PCR mix to each well.
Cover the plate with an adhesive seal, vortex briefly and spin down.
Run PCR to amplify the cDNA.

Pause point: The cDNA can be stored at −20°C for 6 months or longer.
Before starting the purification of cDNA, equilibrate Ampure XP beads at room temperature for 15 min, and then vortex thoroughly to ensure that the beads are properly suspended in the buffer.

Add 16.25 μL of Ampure XP beads (0.65× ratio) to each well of the 96-well plate.
Cover the plate with an adhesive seal, vortex briefly and incubate for 5 min at room temperature.
Place the 96-well plate on the magnetic stand for 5 min.
Wash the beads with 200 μL of 80% (vol/vol) ethanol solution twice.
After removing the washing solution, leave the plate at room temperature for approximately 5 min until the beads have dried completely.
Add 22 μL of EB solution to each well and mix 10 times with the pipet to resuspend the beads.
Incubate the plate off the magnet for 2 min at room temperature.
Place the plate back on the magnet for 2 min or longer.
Transfer 20 μL of supernatant containing clean cDNA into a new 96-well plate.
Pause point: The clean cDNA can be stored at −20°C for 6 months or longer.
Evaluate the quality of the cDNA. Following the manufacturer’s instruction[href=http://www.agilent.com/cs/library/usermanuals/public/quick-guide-dnf-474-hs-ngs-fragment-kit-SD-AT000134.pdf], analyze the size distribution of the cDNA using a HS NGS Fragment Kit on an Agilent Fragment Analyzer Instrument.
Note: A good quality cDNA preparation should be almost free of small fragments (<500 bp) and should peak at ∼1.5–2 kb.
Measure the concentration of cDNA generated from each sample using PicoGreen.
Normalize cDNA to a concentration of 0.1–0.15 ng/μL in nuclease-free water.
Prepare DNA libraries using Nextera XT DNA Library Preparation Kit (Illumina). 0.75 μL of normalized cDNA is used in a miniaturized 15% volume (3 μL total) Nextera tagmentation reaction. Miniaturized reactions are set up in a 384-well plate. Volumes of the following steps are adjusted accordingly. For the detailed information on the Nextera XT kit, refer to the manufacturer’s manual[href=http://genome.med.harvard.edu/documents/libraryPrep/IlluminaNexteraXTProtocol.pdf]. A Mosquito HV liquid-handling robot is used for pipetting.
Pause point: The final libraries can be stored at −20°C.

Prepare a library pool containing 96 libraries by combining 1.2 μL of each final library in one tube.
Purify the library pool with 0.8× Vol Ampure XP beads and elute in 30 μL resuspension buffer.
Evaluate the quality of the library pool with an HS NGS Fragment Kit on an Agilent Fragment Analyzer instrument.
Dilute the library pool to the loading concentration specific for the sequencing system.
Sequence the libraries with e.g., the Illumina NovaSeq 6000 system using a 100 cycles reagent kit and PE 2 × 51 sequencing.
